unit: Unit 9 | Inference for Quantitative Data: Slopes
title: Follow the Bouncing Ball to Determine the $t$-Statistic
question_text:
Jessica was stuck babysitting and was feeling quite bored from watching her little sister Allison bounce a ball up and down. To ease her boredom she decided to keep track of the number of bounces Allison could complete in various amounts of time.
She then developed the equation for the least squares regression line to be:
$$\hat { y } = 2.136+1.021x$$
...where $\hat { y }$ is the predicted number of bounces and $x$ is the number of seconds.
If the standard error of the slope is $0.763$, what $t$-statistic would Jessica arrive at when completing a $t$-test for the linear regression?
solution:
The $t$-value can be calculated using the following formula:

$$t=\dfrac { { b }_{ 1 } }{ SE }$$

...where ${ b }_{ 1 }$ is the slope of the least-squares regression line and $SE$ is the standard error of the slope.

Filling in the formula:

$$t = \dfrac { 1.021 }{ 0.763 } =1.338$$

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect and was calculated by reversing the numerator and denominator in the $t$-statistic.

Choice 'B' is incorrect and represents only the standard error of the slope.

Choice 'C' is incorrect and represents the actual slope of the least-squares regression line.

Choice 'E' is incorrect. It was calculated by mistaking the $y$-intercept from the least-squares regression for the slope.
